6.0  Emergency Response Programs

The City of Alexandria Ground Storage Castor Plunge has prepared a written emergency response plan that complies with the RMP rule, other federal standards and industry guidelines.  This plan has been communicated to the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and local fire department.

7.0  Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The City of Alexandria Ground Storage Castor Plunge continuously attempts to improve the safety of our processes to protect the employees, the public, and the environment.  The City of Alexandria Ground Storage Castor Plunge incident investigations, employee suggestions, and improvement in technology are utilized to update the safety aspects of the processes.

4.6  Compliance Audit

The City of Alexandria Ground Storage Castor Plunge performs periodic (at least every three years) audits of covered processes to verify the processes are operating in compliance with the requirements of the RMP rule.  A compliance audit report is prepared after each audit, and any deficiencies noted by the audit are corrected in a timely manner.

4.7  Incident Investigations

The City of Alexandria Ground Storage Castor Plunge investigates all incidents that could reasonably have resulted in a serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment.  The City of Alexandria Ground Storage Castor Plunge trains employees to identify and report any and all incidents requiring investigation.  An investigation team is assembled and the investigation is initiated within 48 hours of the incident.  The results of the incident are documented, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate process enhancements are implemented.

4.8  Chemical-specific Prevention Steps - Chlorine

Industry standards are followed at The City of Alexandria Ground Storage Castor Plunge to help ensure the safe handling of chlorine.  The vendor supplies chlorine via a Department of Transportation(DOT) approved truck and in DOT approved 1 ton containers.  The process equipment is designed and constructed with state-of-the-art materials and technology utilizing the standards and guidelines of the Chlorine Institute, American Water Works Association, ASME, ANSI, and other applicable codes.  Workers who perform operations involving chlorine receive training emphasizing safe handling procedures according to guidelines required by The City of Alexandria Ground Storage Castor Plunge.

2.0  Description of The City of Alexandria Ground Storage Castor Plunge and Regulated Substances

The City of Alexandria Ground Storage Castor Plunge handles one substance regulated by the Risk Management Plan (RMP) Rule in quantities above the Threshold Quantity.

Chlorine - stored in 1 ton containers and used for disinfection of the water prior to distribution.

3.0  Hazard Assessment

The RMP Rule requires The City of Alexandria Ground Storage Castor Plunge to perform a Hazard Assessment of the regulated substances stored and used in the covered processes at the facility.  The Hazard Assessment includes an offsite consequence analysis for the following scenarios:

One worst-case and one alternative release scenario for the toxic substance chlorine for the chlorination process unit at the facility.

The City of Alexandria Ground Storage Castor Plunge completed a Hazard Assessment for the covered processes and the results have been appropriately communicated to the local emergency response agencies.  The Hazard Assessment has been updated for the current RMP Re-Submission (January 2019).

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The City of Alexandria Ground Storage Castor Plunge is located at 747 Castor Plunge Road, Alexandria, LA.   Chlorine used in the chlorination of the drinking water is stored at this location.  A maximum of 8,000 pounds of chlorine are stored in one ton cylinders.  The City of Alexandria Ground Storage Castor Plunge is included in written community emergency response plan.  In case of a chlorine leak, the City of Alexandria has an emergency response policy which requires City personnel to notify LA State Police Hazmat by calling the 911 center as well as local fire and police departments.  These emergency personnel are used to assist in evacuating citizens in the affected area.  Currently, the City uses daily inspection, leak detection and a comprehensive preventative maintenance program to ensure the system is operating properly.  Plant personnel have been properly trained to handle chlorine stored in one ton cylinders.  Formal and on-the-job training ensures plant personnel have the necessary knowledge and skill to properly maintain the chlorination system.  On-going operator training and preventive maintenance continue to be key tools to ensure the safety of the public.  The City of Alexandria Ground Storage Castor Plunge has no history of reportable release for chlorine.  There have been no injury or property loss associated with this chemical at this site.
